content:
Let kkk be a field. I used to assume the 2 definitions of a kkk-algebra agree: First one, a monoid (A,μ,η)(A,\mu,\eta)(A,μ,η) in the symmetric monoidal category Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​; second one, a ring map η:k→A\eta: k \rightarrow Aη:k→A such that η(k)⊆Z(A)\eta(k) \subseteq Z(A)η(k)⊆Z(A), where Z(A)Z(A)Z(A) is the center of AAA (for clarity, every ring and algebra is unital and associative and I don't assume commutativity).

Now it is clear we can define multiplications in AAA: a⋅b=μ(a⊗b)a \cdot b = \mu(a \otimes b)a⋅b=μ(a⊗b) and the unit is η(1)\eta(1)η(1), so this part of equivalence has no problem, however I cannot find a way to prove η(k)⊆Z(A)\eta(k) \subseteq Z(A)η(k)⊆Z(A) using the monoid definition. Moreover, I don't know if this is even true: We can regard the quaternions H\mathbb{H}H as a C\mathbb{C}C-vector space, and I believe this will make H\mathbb{H}H a monoid; but the centre of H\mathbb{H}H is only R\mathbb{R}R, so the inclusion does not define an algebra if we are using definition 1.

Am I misunderstanding anything, or do these 2 definitions not agree in general?

Starting with the monoid definition you define η(r):=r⋅1\eta(r):=r\cdot 1η(r):=r⋅1. This is in the center because (r⋅1)y=r⋅y=y(r⋅1)(r\cdot 1)y=r\cdot y=y(r\cdot 1)(r⋅1)y=r⋅y=y(r⋅1). Or am I missing something?

@Joe Moeller

I am not sure why r⋅y=y(r⋅1)r\cdot y=y (r \cdot 1)r⋅y=y(r⋅1). Also, maybe this is where I got it wrong but how is y(r⋅1)y(r \cdot 1)y(r⋅1) defined? Are you using the bimodule structure on AAA? I assumed the left and right unitor in Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​ are both scalar multiple on the left but maybe it was to be understood as this bimodule structure where you act on left and right?

I’m using concatenation for the monoid operation and cdot for scalar multiplication. And in general we have y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx)y(r\cdot x)=r\cdot (yx)y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx). Bimodule is a fancy name for vector space in this scenario.
I wouldn't say a vector space is the same as a bimodule; a bimodule might have different left and right actions even when the ring is commutative.

@Joe Moeller

Sorry, but I still don't quite understand this. Why do we have y(r⋅x)=r⋅(xy)y(r \cdot x)=r \cdot (xy)y(r⋅x)=r⋅(xy)? I don't see how that follows from the axioms, specifically what allows us to put yyy after xxx?

Also, can you point out what's wrong with the quaternion counter example?

Mike Shulman said:

I wouldn't say a vector space is the same as a bimodule; a bimodule might have different left and right actions even when the ring is commutative.

I am very confused now-- can you explain to me what the right unitor is? Is it not scalar multiplication on the left?
I think that was a typo, probably Joe meant y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx)y(r\cdot x) = r \cdot (yx)y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx).
But when x=1x=1x=1 we have y1=y=1yy1=y=1yy1=y=1y.

What's wrong with the quaternions is exactly this: the multiplication is not a map H⊗CH→H\mathbb{H}\otimes_{\mathbb{C}}\mathbb{H} \to\mathbb{H}H⊗C​H→H because for instance j(i⋅1)≠i⋅(j1)j(i\cdot 1) \neq i \cdot (j 1)j(i⋅1)=i⋅(j1).

Jack Jia said:

can you explain to me what the right unitor is?

What do you mean by "unitor"?

Mike Shulman said:

I think that was a typo, probably Joe meant y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx)y(r\cdot x) = r \cdot (yx)y(r⋅x)=r⋅(yx).

Yes, sorry. Fixed.

Mike Shulman said:

Jack Jia said:

can you explain to me what the right unitor is?

What do you mean by "unitor"?

By "right unitor" I meant the canonical natural iso V⊗I≅VV \otimes I \cong VV⊗I≅V in a monoidal category (C,⊗,I)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes, I)(C,⊗,I). In Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​, is this still the scalar multiplication of VVV regarded as a left kkk-vector space?
Yes. Since a field kkk is commutative, any left module can also be regarded as a right module, and hence as a bimodule. My point was that not every bimodule is of this form.

Mike Shulman said:

Yes. Since a field kkk is commutative, any left module can also be regarded as a right module, and hence as a bimodule. My point was that not every bimodule is of this form.

So it's actually the right action, but in this case they coincide? For example, if I change the monoidal category to AlgR\mathsf{Alg}_RAlgR​, then a monoid will need to be an RRR-bimodule, is this correct?
If RRR is a commutative ring, then the symmetric monoidal categories of left RRR-modules and of right RRR-modules are isomorphic.
For any ring RRR, there is also a non-symmetric monoidal category of RRR-RRR-bimodules.

Jack Jia said:

We can regard the quaternions H\mathbb{H}H as a C\mathbb{C}C-vector space, and I believe this will make H\mathbb{H}H a monoid;

There's no complex algebra (= monoid object in the monoidal category of complex vector spaces) whose underlying real algebra is H\mathbb{H}H.

There are different ways to prove this. The quickest way is to notice that such a complex algebra would need to be 2-dimensional (i.e. have an 2-dimensional underlying complex vector space), and every 2-dimensional algebra over a field is commutative.

To see the latter fact, notice that every 2-dimensional algebra AAA over a field kkk has a basis 1,x1, x1,x for some x∈Ax \in Ax∈A. Thus element in such an algebra is of the form a1+bxa1 + bxa1+bx for a,b∈ka,b \in ka,b∈k, and all such elements commute.

(But perhaps you're not seeing why all such elements commute?)

John Baez said:

Jack Jia said:

We can regard the quaternions H\mathbb{H}H as a C\mathbb{C}C-vector space, and I believe this will make H\mathbb{H}H a monoid;

There's no complex algebra (= monoid object in the monoidal category of complex vector spaces) whose underlying real algebra is H\mathbb{H}H.

There are different ways to prove this. The quickest way is to notice that such a complex algebra would need to be 2-dimensional (i.e. have an 2-dimensional underlying complex vector space), and every 2-dimensional algebra over a field is commutative.

To see the latter fact, notice that every 2-dimensional algebra AAA over a field kkk has a basis 1,x1, x1,x for some x∈Ax \in Ax∈A. Thus element in such an algebra is of the form a1+bxa1 + bxa1+bx for a,b∈ka,b \in ka,b∈k, and all such elements commute.

(But perhaps you're not seeing why all such elements commute?)

Thanks for the explanation! I think I see that they commute since 111 and xxx both commute with xxx.
Thanks @Joe Moeller and @Mike Shulman for the detailed explanations! I think I understand now

Jack Jia said:

For example, if I change the monoidal category to AlgR\mathsf{Alg}_RAlgR​, then a monoid will need to be an RRR-bimodule, is this correct?

This is a somewhat strange question since you're not saying what RRR is, and you're acting like we know what AlgR\mathsf{Alg}_RAlgR​ is. If RRR is a noncommutative ring, people don't talk about AlgR\mathsf{Alg}_RAlgR​, at least not very often.

If RRR is a noncommutative ring the category of left RRR-modules is not monoidal in a natural way, nor is the category of right RRR-modules. But the category of R,RR, RR,R-bimodules is monoidal. A monoid in here is not usually called an RRR-algebra, because when RRR is commutative it's not the same as the usual concept of RRR-algebra for commutative RRR. I've seen it called an RRR-ring or an RRR-bimodule algebra, and I find the latter term to be clearer.

(Note: I said if RRR is a noncommutative ring the category of left RRR-modules is not monoidal in a natural way. But of course we can sometimes choose a monoidal structure on this category! For example there's a standard way to do this if RRR is a bialgebra. I don't want to get into this too much, but a good example arises when RRR is a group algebra k[G]k[G]k[G] for some field kkk and some group GGG. Then the category of left RRR-modules gets a monoidal structure because it's equivalent to the category of representations of the group GGG on vector spaces over kkk, and this category has a well-known monoidal structure. A monoid in the category of left RRR-modules with this monoidal structure is the same as a kkk-algebra with an action of GGG as automorphisms.)
